newsitem.title: NORWAY: DnB says increasing stake in Fokus to get BNbank.
newsitem.headline: DnB says increasing stake in Fokus to get BNbank.

text.p: Norway's Den norske Bank (DnB) said on Wednesday it had increased its shareholding in Fokus Bank to make it easier to take over mortgage lender Bolig og Naeringsbanken (BNbank).
Both DnB and Fokus are bidding for BNbank.
DnB, Norway's largest bank, said in a statement it had bought five million shares in Fokus corresponding to 7.6 percent of stock in Norway's fourth largest bank.
"The purpose of the share purchase is to increase the chances of DnB being succesful with its takeover bid for BNbank's shareholders," DnB said to describe the tactical acquisition.
It said DnB's wholly-owned subsidiary insurance company Vital separately held 1.6 percent of Fokus shares.
The statement stressed that DnB did not plan to take over Fokus.
It criticised Fokus's proposal to merge with BNbank and noted that BNbank had not expressed any wish to enter into a fusion with Fokus.
BNbank on April 11 said DnB's takeover bid appeared to be good and said it was postponing possible merger talks with rival bidder Fokus.
On Tuesday, at the insistence of Fokus, BNbank's board said it had called an extraordinary general assembly for April 30 to discuss the takeover offer by Fokus.
DnB has given BNbank shareholders until the end of April to accept its cash offer of 209 crowns per share, including a 1996 dividend of 10.50 crowns.
DnB's cash offer values BNbank at 2.04 billion crowns excluding dividend.
Fokus has a share exchange offer valuing BNbank at 2.06 billion crowns.

The situation of Fokus is complicated by a hostile takeover bid launched for it last week by Sparebankgruppen, a group of 16 savings banks. The board of Fokus on Monday recommended its shareholders turn down Sparebankgruppen's bid and did not rule out other bids may come soon.
Sparebankgruppen said it was bidding 73 crowns per share for Fokus, which it valued at 4.80 billion.
